These Turkey Meatballs Are the Only Meal Prep I’ll Eat 3 Days in a Row | Bon Appétit




Skip to main contentOpen Navigation MenuMenuStory SavedTo revisit this article, visit My Profile, then View saved stories.Close AlertCloseStory SavedTo revisit this article, select My Account, then View saved storiesClose AlertCloseSign InSearchRecipesCookingCultureShoppingRestaurantsBA MarketVideosPodcastMerch ShopcookingThese Turkey Meatballs Are the Only Meal Prep I’ll Eat 3 Days in a RowThey taste like banh mi—banh meatballs, if you will—and I can't get enough.By Alyse WhitneyJune 8, 2018FacebookTwitterEmailCutler CraigFacebookTwitterEmailWelcome to Never Fail, a weekly column where we wax poetic about the recipes that never, ever let us down.A few years ago, I tried every single meal kit box for a story I was working on. My fridge was full of pre-portioned ingredient packages, and I longed for literally anything else to eat after that very long month. But there was one meal that I kept making for months and years afterward: banh mi turkey burgers. Martha Stewart’s recipe (from the Martha & Marley Spoon box) was straightforward, flavorful, and the only reason I would ever buy ground turkey. They had all the flavors of a Vietnamese banh mi sandwich in burger form, using fish sauce, scallions, garlic, Sriracha, cornstarch to bind, and a tiny bit sugar for balance. Quick-pickled vegetables, cilantro, and Sriracha mayonnaise went on top and pulled the whole thing together. The patties were juicy and springy and and so flavorful—it was a transformative turkey experience.Then, while moving apartments, I lost the XL recipe card and Googled the recipe one day. Instead of Martha’s recipe, I found a 2010 Bon Appétit recipe for pork meatball banh mi sandwiches. They were made with ground pork instead of turkey, but had a lot of the same ingredients, so I gave the recipe a try, swapping ground turkey for the pork. I used an ice cream scoop to portion out meatball sizes, rolled them out, and then gently pressed them into little slider patties. Whenever I cook meatballs on the stovetop, they don't brown evenly and roll around. Usually I opt to oven-roast them, but I was in a hurry and knew that sliders would cook through quickly.Quick pickled vegetables + banh meatballs = my favorite meal.
Photo by Alex Lau, Food Styling by Susie TheodorouAfter cooking about four minutes per side, they were done, and just as juicy and flavorful as I remembered. I plopped three of them on top of a bowl of rice, drizzled on some spicy mayo, and topped it all with cilantro, scallions, and quick-pickled carrots (those pre-shredded carrots from the store soaked in rice vinegar, salt, and sugar). Bingo, bongo—a rice bowl for dinner, and easy to portion out for meals for the week. It was accidental meal prep the first time, but they reheated so well and were so satisfying that I do it at least once a month. I know the recipe by heart now, and even though I know they'd taste damn good if I used pork, I always use turkey out of habit.I try to meal prep at least once or twice a week, but often get sick of what I make after a day or two. Not these! I can eat them three days in a row, and then am a little disappointed the next day when they’re gone. They are pretty healthyish—even more so if I serve them over greens instead of rice—and cook in 30 minutes or less, so they're super weeknight-friendly. The BA recipe calls for pickled daikon and jalapeños, but I sweat when I eat spicy things and I can’t always find daikon, so I just use whatever fresh, crunchy things I have lying around. The toppings can be whatever you want, honestly. Once I forgot to pickle veg, so I got some raw scallions and carrots from the cafeteria to top my bowl. It did not suck.When I microwave these bad boys at the office, somebody will shout out, without fail: “What smells so good?” I say “banh meatballs,” even though that’s technically not true since they’re flat, but I can’t resist a pun. Or a turkey slider.
